title: Disclaimer
subtitle: Boxing is powerful — but it's not without risk. This section outlines the essential safety guidelines you must understand before using DreamBoxing. Prioritize your health, consult a doctor, and never train without proper supervision.

steps.text: DreamBoxing is designed as an educational tool to help users learn about the fundamentals of boxing technique. However, boxing is a physically demanding and potentially dangerous activity, and all exercises and techniques demonstrated in this app should be performed under the supervision of a qualified professional instructor.

Before beginning any new exercise program, including boxing training, you should always consult with a medical professional to ensure you are physically fit to participate. If at any point during training you experience chest pain, dizziness, shortness of breath, or any other concerning symptoms, stop immediately and seek medical attention.

By using this app, you acknowledge and agree that you are solely responsible for your own safety and well-being. The creators, developers, and publishers of DreamBoxing accept no liability for any injury, accident, or harm, whether direct or indirect, that may result from your use of this app or from participating in any of the exercises or techniques demonstrated.

Always practice boxing in a safe, controlled environment, using appropriate protective equipment and following proper safety protocols at all times. We also recommend not sparring (practice-fighting) unless you are fully supervised by a trained professional. Sparring is not something to take lightly - many boxers attribute their health deterioration in later life to hard-sparring.

takeaways: Consult a medical professional before starting any new boxing or exercise program — your safety comes first.
You are solely responsible for your own health and training choices; DreamBoxing cannot and will not accept liability for injuries or accidents.
Never spar without full supervision from a trained coach — sparring carries serious long-term risks if done incorrectly or unsafely. You can enjoy all the benefits of boxing without sparring.

title: Why Boxing?
subtitle: Discover what makes boxing a powerful way to train your body and mind. Unlock your full potential through the art of Boxing.

steps.text: Focus inward — boxing clears the noise in your mind.
Find your flow — every punch becomes a moving meditation. Challenge yourself — and feel calmer, sharper, stronger. Have fun and enhance your physical and mental wellbeing.

takeaways: Boxing enhances mental clarity, focus and confidence.
It’s a full-body workout — combining strength, cardio, and agility.
It’s empowering and accessible — you don’t need a ring to train like a boxer.

title: Stance: Orthodox or Southpaw?
subtitle: Choose your stance and understand how to follow along. The majority of people will be suited to an Orthodox boxing stance.

steps.text: Orthodox Stance: If your right hand is stronger, your left foot and hand will lead. Your power hand stays at the back.
Southpaw Stance: If your left hand is stronger, typically, your right foot and hand will lead. Your left power hand stays at the back.
One Approach, Both Stances: In this app, all instructions assume Orthodox stance, but we’ll always refer to your lead and rear sides.

takeaways: Orthodox = left foot/hand lead, power hand rear (right-handed).
Southpaw = right foot/hand lead, power hand rear (left-handed).
This app assumes Orthodox stance, but all instructions work for both — just mirror them based on your lead/rear sides.

title: Making a Fist Correctly
subtitle: Look after your hands. Understand how to make a fist correctly and position of fist and forearm on impact with a heavy bag or an opponent.

steps.text: Hold your hand out. Keep the fingers close together but in a relaxed fashion.
First, roll the top part of your fingers into the base of your fingers, not your palm.
Squeeze fingers into hand.
Now, lock your thumb over your fingers.
Once you lock your thumb, you should feel your forearm ‘lock’, with no bend in your wrist.

takeaways: Start with an open hand — fingers straight. Curl fingers down, then place thumb across the outside of the fingers.
Strike with the first two knuckles and keep the fist tight but natural.
Be aware of your forearm and fist. Ensure your forearm is ‘locked’ and there isn’t any bend in your wrist.

title: Wrapping Your Hands
subtitle: Protect your tools — learn to wrap your hands the right way. Opt for long wraps that are approximately 180 inches long, to get the best full-hand support. Your wrap should be snug, not too tight, which will limit your ability to clench your fist.

steps.text: Place your thumb through the loop of the wrap and place it on the back of your palm as shown.
From here, wrap your wrist 3 times.
Then, wrap your palm 3 times.
Now, secure your thumb. Do so by going over the back of your thumb then back again, then wrapping your wrist.
Bring the wrap around from your wrist as shown.
Now, go from your thumb diagonally across the back of your palm in between your little finger and your ring finger.
Take the wrap across the inside of your palm and then in between your thumb and index finger and then back across the back of your hand. You should see an ‘X’ form, as shown here.

Now, repeat the process going in between your middle and ring finger, and then in between your index and middle, always repeating the ‘X’ across the back of your hand by going in between your thumb and index finger.
Your wrap should look like this.
Once you have wrapped your fingers, go once again around your palm and then finish off by securing the wrap around your wrist.

takeaways: Always start through the thumb loop, wrapping the wrist and palm first for a solid foundation.
Create an ‘X’ pattern on the back of your hand by weaving the wrap between your fingers.
Finish by securing the wrap around your wrist for firm, comfortable support.
